disease.label: Intellectual developmental disorder with dysmorphic facies and behavioral abnormalities

term.label: Intellectual developmental disorder with dysmorphic facies and behavioral abnormalities

resources.name: An Online Catalog of Human Genes and Genetic Disorders

externalReferences.description: De Novo Variants in the F-Box Protein FBXO11 in 20 Individuals with a Variable Neurodevelopmental Disorder

query:
From the following patient information, what is the most likely diagnosis? Use multiple queries or reasoning steps as necessary, and provide a rank-ordered list of up to 10 diagnoses, even if there is insufficient information to make a definitive diagnosis. If you are unsure, provide a list of possible diagnoses with the most likely one first.

Patient ID: Individual 4
Patient age: 8 years
Patient sex: Male
Patient features: Microcephaly, Hypotonia, Autistic behavior, Global developmental delay, Delayed ability to walk, Delayed speech and language development, Intellectual disability, Seizure, Short stature, Bulbous nose, Narrow mouth, Macrotia, Long eyelashes, Long philtrum, Narrow palpebral fissure, Anteverted nares, Short nose, Broad eyebrow, Pointed chin, Brachycephaly, Small hand, Broad foot, Clinodactyly, Bifid uvula, Slender long bone, Osteopenia, Delayed skeletal maturation, Recurrent respiratory infections, Strabismus, Tube feeding.
Excluded patient features: Sleep onset insomnia, Developmental regression, Sparse eyebrow, High palate, Blepharochalasis, Broad nasal tip, Epicanthus, Long palpebral fissure, Long face, Frontal bossing, Broad forehead, Full cheeks, Retrognathia, Prominent tragus, Short philtrum, Preauricular pit, Everted lower lip vermilion, Thin upper lip vermilion, Highly arched eyebrow, Micrognathia, Periorbital fullness, Smooth philtrum, Low-set ears, Wide mouth, Prominent nose, Frontal upsweep of hair, Abnormally large globe, Downslanted palpebral fissures, Depressed nasal ridge, Thick lower lip vermilion, Prominent nasal bridge, Triangular face, Mandibular prognathia, Hypertelorism, Protruding ear, Wide nasal bridge, Coarse facial features, Tented upper lip vermilion, Proptosis, Tapered finger, Toe syndactyly, Sandal gap, Single transverse palmar crease, Short palm, Bilateral camptodactyly, Arachnodactyly, Pes planus, Broad distal phalanx of finger, Deep plantar creases, Cleft lip, Short uvula, Joint hypermobility, Sagittal craniosynostosis, Metopic synostosis, Esodeviation, Atrial septal defect, Pneumothorax, Pectus excavatum of inferior sternum, Striae distensae, Hypermetropia, Cubitus valgus, Vomiting, Recurrent otitis media, Asthma, Ankyloglossia, Gastroesophageal reflux, Primary amenorrhea, Syringomyelia, Cryptorchidism, Hirsutism, Aortic aneurysm, Duane anomaly, Constipation, High myopia, Hyperhidrosis.

messages.content:
To provide a rank-ordered list of possible diagnoses for this patient, I will analyze the provided phenotypic features and excluded features. I will query the Monarch knowledge graph to identify diseases that match the patient's features and exclude those that conflict with the excluded features. This process will involve the following steps:

1. **Search for diseases associated with the patient's phenotypic features**: I will query the graph for diseases linked to the provided features.
2. **Filter out diseases that conflict with excluded features**: Diseases that are associated with excluded features will be deprioritized or removed.
3. **Rank the remaining diseases**: Based on the number of matching features and the rarity of the disease, I will rank the possible diagnoses.

Let me begin by searching for diseases associated with the patient's phenotypic features.

messages.name: search

messages.content:
I have identified a large number of phenotypic features and their associated diseases or conditions. To narrow down the list of possible diagnoses, I will now focus on diseases that match multiple features simultaneously. This will help prioritize conditions that align closely with the patient's presentation.

Next, I will query the knowledge graph to find diseases associated with combinations of these features.

intellectual disability - autism spectrum disorder', 'name': 'ADNP-related multiple congenital anomalies - intellectual disability - autism spectrum disorder', 'description': 'An autosomal dominant non-syndromic intellectual disability that has material basis in an autosomal dominant mutation of ADNP on chromosome 20q13.13.', 'category': 'biolink:Disease', 'label': 'biolink:Disease'}}, {'data': {'id': 'MONDO:0010407', 'caption': 'intellectual disability, X-linked syndromic, Turner type', 'name': 'intellectual disability, X-linked syndromic, Turner type', 'description': 'An X-linked syndromic intellectual disability characterized by moderate to severe intellectual deficit in boys and moderate intellectual deficit in girls. It has been described in 14 members from four generations of one family. Macrocephaly was reported and holoprosencephaly may also be present (two family members). The mode of transmission is X-linked semi-dominant.', 'category': 'biolink:Disease', 'label': 'biolink:Disease'}}, {'data': {'id': 'MONDO:0011518', 'caption': 'Wiedemann-Steiner syndrome', 'name': 'Wiedemann-Steiner syndrome', 'description': 'Wiedemann-Steiner syndrome is a rare genetic condition characterized by distinctive facial features, hairy elbows, short stature, and intellectual disability. This condition is caused by changes (mutations) in the KMT2A gene (also known as the MLL gene). It is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. Most cases result from new (de novo) mutations that occur only in an egg or sperm cell, or just after conception. Treatment is symptomatic and supportive and may include special education classes and speech and occupational therapies aimed at increasing motor functioning and language.', 'category': 'biolink:Disease', 'label': 'biolink:Disease'}}, {'data': {'id': 'MONDO:0009910', 'caption': 'Wiedemann-Rautenstrauch syndrome', 'name': 'Wiedemann-Rautenstrauch syndrome', 'description': 'Wiedemann-Rautenstrauch syndrome is a very rare disorder with features of premature aging recognizable at birth, decreased subcutaneous fat, hypotrichosis, relative macrocephaly and dysmorphism.', 'category': 'biolink:Disease', 'label': 'biolink:Disease'}}, {'data': {'id': 'MONDO:0011053', 'caption': 'intellectual disability-sparse hair-brachydactyly syndrome', 'name': 'intellectual disability-sparse hair-brachydactyly syndrome', 'description': 'Intellectual disability-sparse hair-brachydactyly syndrome is a very rare condition of unknown etiology consisting of short stature, hypotrichosis, brachydactyly with cone-shaped epiphyses, epilepsy and severe mental delay. After the initial delineation of this syndrome by Nicolaides and Baraitser in 1993, only five more patients were published in the literature up to now.', 'category': 'biolink:Disease', 'label': 'biolink:Disease'}}, {'data': {'id': 'MONDO:0007617', 'caption': 'Coffin-Siris syndrome 1', 'name': 'Coffin-Siris syndrome 1', 'description': 'Any Coffin-Siris syndrome in which the cause of the disease is a mutation in the ARID1B gene.', 'category': 'biolink:Disease', 'label': 'biolink:Disease'}}], 'edges': []}}, 'result_as_table': {'type': 'table', 'data': []}}
messages.name: run_query

messages.content:
Based on the analysis of the patient's phenotypic features, the following rank-ordered list of possible diagnoses has been identified. These diseases are associated with multiple features presented by the patient:

1. **[Intellectual developmental disorder with dysmorphic facies and behavioral abnormalities](https://monarchinitiative.org/MONDO:0060760)**
2. **[Intellectual disability-feeding difficulties-developmental delay-microcephaly syndrome](https://monarchinitiative.org/MONDO:0014213)**
3. **[Chromosome 15q24 deletion syndrome](https://monarchinitiative.org/MONDO:0013256)**: A rare chromosomal anomaly characterized by growth retardation, intellectual disability, distinct facial features, and skeletal anomalies.
4. **[Chromosome 2q32-q33 deletion syndrome](https://monarchinitiative.org/MONDO:0012864)**: A syndrome with intellectual deficit, speech delay, feeding difficulties, growth retardation, and dysmorphic features.
5. **[ADNP-related multiple congenital anomalies - intellectual disability - autism spectrum disorder](https://monarchinitiative.org/MONDO:0014379)**: An autosomal dominant condition with intellectual disability, autism spectrum disorder, and congenital anomalies.
6. **[Intellectual disability, X-linked syndromic, Turner type](https://monarchinitiative.org/MONDO:0010407)**: A condition with intellectual disability, macrocephaly, and possible holoprosencephaly.
7. **[Wiedemann-Steiner syndrome](https://monarchinitiative.org/MONDO:0011518)**: A genetic condition with distinctive facial features, short stature, and intellectual disability.
8. **[Wiedemann-Rautenstrauch syndrome](https://monarchinitiative.org/MONDO:0009910)**: A rare disorder with features of premature aging, macrocephaly, and dysmorphism.
9. **[Intellectual disability-sparse hair-brachydactyly syndrome](https://monarchinitiative.org/MONDO:0011053)**: A rare condition with short stature, hypotrichosis, brachydactyly, epilepsy, and severe mental delay.
10. **[Coffin-Siris syndrome 1](https://monarchinitiative.org/MONDO:0007617)**: A syndrome caused by mutations in the ARID1B gene, associated with intellectual disability and dysmorphic features.

These conditions are prioritized based on the number of matching features and their relevance to the patient's presentation. Further clinical evaluation, genetic testing, and consultation with a specialist are recommended to refine the diagnosis.

expected_diagnosis_mondo.disease_name: intellectual developmental disorder with dysmorphic facies and behavioral abnormalities
